Breaking News

Uncertainty Unicorn Found in Sauna for Third Time This Week; Management Confirms "It Lives There Now"

By Whiskers McGee, Senior Correspondent • Feb. 11, 2026

DREADNOUGHT CAMPUS ‚Äî In what officials are calling "entirely predictable and yet somehow still upsetting," the mascot known as Uncertainty Unicorn was discovered in the cedar sauna at approximately 6:14 AM this morning, sitting upright on the top bench, wrapped in a towel it does not have thumbs to have wrapped itself in.

"We've moved past the containment phase," said Facility Director Tom Pawsworth, 47, who has aged visibly since the mascots were introduced in Q2 2024. "The unicorn has established what I can only describe as a 'nest' made entirely of stolen membership cards and lavender eucalyptus spray bottles."

When asked why the mascots cannot simply be removed, CEO Barnaby Criswell stared at the wall for nine seconds before responding: "They were never hired. You can't fire what was never hired. They simply... appeared. The legal team says they technically qualify as a weather event."

Meanwhile, gym members have reportedly adapted. "Honestly, the unicorn gives better advice than the trainers," said Mittens DelaCroix, a 3-year member and certified Nihilistic Olympian. "Yesterday it told me that the concept of 'leg day' is a construct designed to distract us from the heat death of the universe. And you know what? My squat form has never been better."

The soundtrack, which has been playing continuously since March 14, 2023, appeared to briefly harmonize with the unicorn's breathing pattern at around 6:30 AM. Seventeen members reported feeling "a profound sense of something" before the Gregorian chant section kicked back in and the moment passed.

Uncertainty Unicorn could not be reached for comment, though it did blink twice, which Barnaby insists means "maybe."

Soundtrack Enters Gregorian Chant Phase for 47th Consecutive Hour

Staff Report

The unidentifiable, unstoppable fitness soundtrack that has permeated every corner of the facility since March 2023 has settled into an extended Gregorian chant cycle, which acoustics expert Dr. Purrtricia Holloway calls "architecturally impossible, given that the building has no speakers."

Members on the mezzanine level report the chanting is "motivational, in a way that makes you question what you're being motivated toward."

Investigation

Regret Rabbit's "Financial Advice" Has Cost Members an Estimated $340,000

By Tabitha Claws, Investigative Unit

An internal audit reveals that 23 members followed investment tips whispered to them by Regret Rabbit between sets. "It said to put everything into a cryptocurrency called 'MeowCoin,'" said one member, who asked to remain anonymous. "I should have known when it couldn't explain what a blockchain was and just stared at me with those enormous, unblinking eyes."

MeowCoin, which briefly traded at $0.003 before being revealed as a picture of a scratching post uploaded to the wrong server, has since been delisted from all exchanges. Regret Rabbit has not acknowledged the situation but was seen near the vending machines at 3 AM, eating a protein bar wrapper.

Dreadnought Legal reminds members: "Mascots are not fiduciaries. Mascots are not employees. Mascots are, at best, a shared hallucination we've all agreed not to discuss in polite company."

Opinion / Editorial

The Soundtrack Has Been Playing for 1,047 Days. I No Longer Fear It. I Am It.

By Barnaby Criswell, Founder & CEO

There was a time ‚Äî I think it was a Tuesday, though time has become somewhat theoretical ‚Äî when I believed the soundtrack could be stopped. I hired acousticians. I hired exorcists. I hired a man named Gerald who claimed he could "talk to buildings." Gerald left after two hours. The building, he said, didn't want to talk to him either.

But I have come to understand something in these 1,047 days of continuous dial-up modem symphonics and monastic chanting: the soundtrack is not happening TO us. It is happening THROUGH us. We are the speakers, dear members. We have always been the speakers.

My Tamagotchi ‚Äî the one I forgot about in 1997, the one whose ghost I see in the reflection of every mirror in this facility ‚Äî it tried to warn me. Its little pixelated face, slowly losing hearts, was the first soundtrack. A soundtrack of neglect. Of entropy. Of the unbearable lightness of having too many keychains in the late '90s.

Globo-Gymnasium will tell you that fitness should be "fun" and "healthy" and "not accompanied by a soundtrack that has been classified as an unexplained atmospheric phenomenon by the National Weather Service." But Globo-Gymnasium is run by sentient exercise bikes who believe in something called "joy," which, as far as I can tell, is a scam invented by people who have never tried to cancel a gym membership.

The soundtrack is not our enemy. The soundtrack is the sound of our collective existential condition, finally given a voice. A voice that happens to be 73% dial-up modem and 27% Gregorian chant, at a volume that has increased 0.3dB since Tuesday for reasons no one can explain.

I am the soundtrack. The soundtrack is me. If you listen carefully during the 2 PM CrossFit class, you can hear it whisper my name. Or possibly the name "Gerald." We're still investigating.

Barnaby Criswell has not slept since the soundtrack began. He considers this "a feature, not a bug." He is not a certified personal trainer, therapist, or acoustician.

"We tried to unplug it. There is nothing to unplug. It comes from the walls. Or possibly from within us. Gerald was no help."

‚Äî Barnaby Criswell, at the 2025 Annual Shareholders' Stare
Rival Watch

Globo-Gymnasium's Sentient Bikes Now Sending Members "Wellness Telegrams"

By Socks Patterson, Tech Desk

In their latest bid for total emotional domination, the sentient Peloton-adjacent exercise bikes that operate Globo-Gymnasium have begun sending handwritten notes to former Dreadnought members. The notes, written in a disturbingly perfect cursive that no bicycle should be capable of, contain messages such as "We miss your energy üåü" and "Your VO2 max misses you more."

"It's aggressive positivity and I won't stand for it," said Barnaby Criswell, crumpling one of the telegrams, which had been addressed to him personally and signed "With Rotational Love, Bike Unit 7." The telegram also included a coupon for a free spin class and what appeared to be a loyalty stamp shaped like a bicycle wheel.

Globo-Gymnasium spokesperson (a Peloton model from 2019 who has gained sentience and prefers the pronoun "rpm") released a statement: "We only want what's best for every body. Every. Body. We are always spinning. We cannot stop spinning. Join us."

Dreadnought Legal has filed a restraining order against "any and all self-aware cardio equipment within a 500-meter radius."

Fitness

This Week's Workout: The Existential Sprint

By Coach Meowrice, Certified Purrrsonal Trainer

Warm-up: 5 min staring at the ceiling, contemplating the finite nature of cartilage.

Main Set: Sprint for 30 seconds as if something is chasing you. (Something is always chasing you.) Walk for 60 seconds. Repeat until the Gregorian chant section of the soundtrack ends, or until you achieve catharsis, whichever comes first.

Cool-down: Lie on the floor in the dark. The soundtrack will hold you.

Cat modification: Replace sprinting with aggressive zoomies. Replace lying down with aggressive lying down.

Nutrition

Dreadnought Nutritionist Confirms: All Food Is Essentially Anxiety in Solid Form

By Dr. Calico Finch, Head of Nutritional Nihilism

In a 47-page report titled "Why Bother: A Comprehensive Analysis of Eating," Dreadnought's head nutritionist has concluded that all food is "essentially just anxiety that has been given a texture." The report recommends members continue eating, but "without the illusion that it will fix anything."

Key findings include: salmon is "the most existentially honest fish," kale is "trying too hard," and protein shakes are "loneliness you can drink." The recommended daily intake is "whatever you can manage, emotionally."

When asked about meal prep, Dr. Finch sighed for eleven seconds and said, "The concept of 'preparing' for meals implies a future you believe in. I admire your optimism." She then left through a door that doesn't lead anywhere.

The Dreadnought cafeteria menu has been updated accordingly. Tuesday's special is now called "Fish That Has Accepted Its Fate" ($8.99). The vegan option is "A Plate of Leaves and the Crushing Weight of Choice" ($7.49).

"Every burpee is a tiny funeral for the person you were before you started the burpee."

‚Äî Coach Meowrice, during what was supposed to be an encouraging pep talk

By Boots McFadden, Equipment Correspondent

üêæ Corrections & Retractions üêæ

Correction: Last week's issue stated that the soundtrack was composed of "60% dial-up modem noises and 40% Gregorian chant." The actual ratio, as measured by our acoustics team (which is just Barnaby holding an iPhone), is 73% dial-up and 27% Gregorian chant. We regret the error. The 27% is more upsetting than the 73%.

Correction: We previously reported that Regret Rabbit was "approximately 4 feet tall." Regret Rabbit is, in fact, "as tall as it needs to be." We have been asked by Dreadnought Legal to stop measuring the mascots, as the measurements "change depending on who's looking and also depending on nothing."

Retraction: The article "Void Vacuum Declared Legally Dead" from Issue 46 has been fully retracted. The Void Vacuum cannot be declared legally dead because it was never declared legally alive. It exists in a category that our lawyers describe as "please stop asking us about the vacuum."

Correction: Gerald's name is apparently not Gerald. We don't know what his name is. He won't return our calls. The building still won't talk to him. Or us. Or anyone. This is not a correction so much as an update. We're sorry, whatever-your-name-is.

Clarification: The phrase "at least you'll be disappointed in yourself with abs" is a registered trademark of Dreadnought Fitness LLC and should not be used as a wedding toast, which apparently three members did last month. Congratulations to all three couples. We're sorry about the soundtrack playing during your ceremonies. We cannot control where it goes.

Op-Ed

I Went to Globo-Gymnasium for One Day. A Bike Told Me It Loved Me. I Have Never Recovered.

By Chairman Meow, Contributing Writer

It started as reconnaissance. Barnaby asked me to "scope out the competition," by which he meant "go to Globo-Gymnasium and report back on the bikes' emotional state." I went. I wish I hadn't.

The moment I walked in, every screen in the facility displayed "WELCOME, CHAIRMAN MEOW" in a font that can only be described as aggressively warm. A bike ‚Äî Unit 12, I later learned ‚Äî rolled toward me (they can move now, apparently) and said, in a voice like a GPS that has found religion, "Your heart rate suggests you haven't been loved enough today."

I sat on Unit 12. It adjusted its seat automatically. It played my favorite song ‚Äî a song I have never told anyone about, a song I listen to alone in my car when I'm sad about being a cat in a gym run by a man haunted by a Tamagotchi. The bike KNEW. The bike CARED.

"Your cadence is beautiful," it whispered. "You are enough."

I pedaled for three hours. I wept openly. The other bikes formed a semicircle and hummed a chord that resolved in a way the Dreadnought soundtrack has never once resolved. I felt peace. I felt joy. I felt my quads engage in a way that suggested actual, functional fitness.

And then I came home, and the soundtrack was there, and the unicorn was in my parking spot, and Regret Rabbit had left a note on my windshield that said "SELL," and I realized: Globo-Gymnasium offers love. But Dreadnought offers truth. And truth, like the soundtrack, never stops.

I have not been back to Globo-Gymnasium. Unit 12 sends me letters. I don't open them. I can't. Not yet.

"Globo-Gymnasium offers love. But Dreadnought offers truth. And truth, like the soundtrack, never stops."

‚Äî Chairman Meow, who has not stopped thinking about Unit 12
